Table 1 Samples mCu (wt. %) mAl (wt. %) Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 92.24 3.69 Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(111)-260 91.65 3.52 Research Paper Boosting methanol steam reforming performance via crystal-facet-mediated inverse Al2O3/Cu catalyst: Regulated electron interaction and reaction pathway Bifeng Yin Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Conceptualization ⁎ HongQi Wang Writing – original draft Visualization Investigation Shengfang Shi Supervision Methodology Data curation Zheng Wei Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Data curation Zhiling Chen Validation Supervision Formal analysis School of Automotive and Traffic Engineering, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang 212013, China School of Automotive and Traffic Engineering Jiangsu University Zhenjiang 212013 China School of Automotive and Traffic Engineering, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang 212013, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Copper-based alumina (Cu/Al2O3) catalysts are promising for low-temperature methanol steam reforming. However, the susceptibility of Cu species to sinter in the reaction atmosphere significantly compromises their stability and intrinsic activity. In this study, we developed crystal-facet-mediated inverse Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O catalysts with triphasic interfaces, exhibiting excellent performance for methanol steam reforming. Under optimal conditions, the Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 catalysts featuring exposed (100) facets activated at 260 °C achieved the optimal hydrogen production rate of 6.91 mmol·g-1·h-1 and the lowest apparent activation energy of 56.99 kJ/mol among comparable systems. This superior performance was attributed to the enhanced strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) at the triphasic interfaces of encapsulated Al2O3 overlayer on Cu/Cu2O(100). This interaction accelerated interfacial electron transfer from Cu to Al2O3, thereby facilitating the generation of oxygen vacancies (OVs) while suppressing the reduction of Cu2O to metallic Cu. Consequently, the SMSI-driven process enhanced the stability of the critical Cu+ sites. In addition, the metastable Cu (100) facet, possessing a loosely arranged atomic structure, further intensified the interaction between Cu and Al2O3, thus forming more OVs than the densely packed Cu (111) facet. The combination of in situ DRIFTs, CH3OHH2O TPSR, and CH3OH-TPD analyses revealed the *HCOOCH3 pathway on inverse Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 catalysts with accelerated steps of continuous dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde (CH3OH → HCHO) and hydrolysis of methanol methyl formate (HCOOCH3 + H2O → HCOO- + CH3OH), resulting in the excellent MSR activity. This work highlights the critical role of facet-dependent SMSIs and interfacial engineering for efficient hydrogen production. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methanol steam reforming Cu+-Cu0 sites Inverse Al2O3/Cu structure Strong metal-support interaction HCOOCH3 pathway Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Rapid depletion of resources and escalating environmental challenges have intensified the demand for clean and sustainable energy alternatives. Hydrogen is an emerging potential substitute for fossil fuels owing to its high energy content per mass unit and clean combustion products, playing a crucial role in achieving a cleaner energy landscape [1–3]. However, conventional high-pressure hydrogen storage technologies pose safety and transportation challenges, limiting their application [4,5]. Methane (CH4), produced through the anaerobic digestion of organic matter, is a key component of biogas and represents a promising renewable energy source. However, hydrogen production through methane reforming often requires temperatures above 700 °C, posing challenges of energy consumption and catalyst stability [6]. Considering the widespread availability of methanol, adopting online methanol steam reforming (MSR) to produce hydrogen eliminates reliance on high-pressure hydrogen and presents a feasible solution for addressing the challenges associated with conventional high-pressure hydrogen storage technologies. Methanol has a relatively high H/C ratio, indicating more hydrogen can be produced per unit mass of the fuel [7]. Meanwhile, the MSR reaction occurs at relatively mild conditions, usually between 200 °C and 300 °C, which is significantly lower than the temperatures required for methane reforming [8]. Moreover, methanol is easier to store and transport than hydrogen. Additionally, it is a liquid at room temperature and pressure, making it possible to be stored and transported using existing infrastructure, such as pipelines and storage tanks [9]. Owing to the advantages of methanol, online methanol steam reforming (MSR, CH3OH + H2O → 3H2 + CO2) integrated with high-temperature proton exchange membrane fuel cells (MSR@HT-PEMFCs) provide a promising alternative route for hydrogen utilization [9–11]. MSR process, a core route for hydrogen (H2) production, comprises one primary reaction and two critical side reactions, with the water–gas shift (WGS) reaction playing a pivotal role in mitigating harmful by-products. MSR (Eq. (1)) is an endothermic reaction, in which methanol (CH3OH) reacts with water (H2O) to generate carbon dioxide (CO2) and H2 [12]. The decomposition of methanol to carbon monoxide (CO) and H2 (Eq. (2)) is a side reaction common to MSR [13]. To address this issue, the WGS reaction (Eq. (3)) occurs as a second side reaction, where CO reacts with H2O to form CO2 and additional H2. This exothermic reaction eliminates toxic CO and enhances the overall H2 yield, ensuring catalyst activity and MSR efficiency [14]. MSR reaction: (1) C H 3 OH + H 2 O → C O 2 + 3 H 2 Decomposition of Methanol: (2) C H 3 OH → CO + 2 H 2 Water - gas shift reaction: (3) CO + H 2 O → C O 2 + H 2 However, developing MSR catalysts with high activity, low CO selectivity, and excellent stability to meet the CO tolerance requirements of HT-PEMFCs (<3 % CO) remains challenging [15,16]. Platinum-group metal (Pt, Ru, and Pd)-based catalysts have attracted considerable attention for MSR [17–18]. Although it can effectively catalyze the dehydrogenation of methanol into CO, its relatively poor ability to dissociate H2O limits the overall efficiency of the methanol reforming reaction, making the H2O dissociation process the rate-determining step and necessitating a higher temperature for the reaction (>300 °C) [19–21]. The optimization of the support and its interface structure can partially enhance the H2O dissociation performance (e.g., CeO2–CoOx composite oxides), but the practical impact remains insignificant [22–23]. Copper-based catalysts (e.g., Cu/ZnO/Al2O3) are cost-effective alternatives. However, they are limited by low Tammann temperatures (∼407 °C) [24–26], sintering-induced deactivation, and sluggish dehydrogenation kinetics at low temperatures (<240 °C). Moreover, traditional Cu-based catalysts struggle to balance Cu0 (active for methanol dehydrogenation) and Cu+ (critical for suppressing HCHO dehydrogenation to CO), resulting in unsatisfactory CO selectivity (>10 %) [27–30]. To address these limitations, catalysts with inverse architectures, where active metal phases are encapsulated by oxide overlayers (e.g., Al2O3), are used. Inverse oxide/metal catalysts are excellent systems for investigating the role of the oxide and oxide-metal interface in catalytic reactions [31]. For instance, traditional reducible oxides, including TiO2, CeOx, and ZnO, act as encapsulation overlayers on transition metals, such as Au, Pd, and Ni. In the case of TiO2-coated Au nanoparticles, high-temperature reduction can induce a defective TiO2 overlayer through strong metal-support interaction, effectively inhibiting Au particle sintering during reactions, such as CO oxidation [32]. Studies have shown that after long-term reaction at high temperatures, the Au particle size remains stable. CeOx overlayers on Pt/Rh nanoparticles can encapsulate the metals, restricting their growth during methane reforming due to the ability of CeOx to tune the electronic structure of the metal-oxide interface and the concentration of interfacial OVs, thereby enhancing reactant adsorption and activation [33]. Similarly, ZnO overlayers on transition metals act as protective layers, suppressing particle sintering during catalytic reactions. In Au/ZnO systems, an O2-induced process forms a thin ZnO overlayer, which inhibits Au nanoparticle sintering and modifies the electronic structure of Au, thereby enhancing catalytic activity [34,35]. In this study, the crystal-facet-mediated inverse Al2O3/Cu catalysts containing a triple-phase interface were successfully constructed. Among them, the highly dispersed encapsulated Al2O3 overlayer significantly facilitated electron transfers from Cu to Al2O3 species, thereby enhancing the metal-support strong interaction (SMSI) and stabilizing the critical Cu+ sites in Cu/Cu2O structures. The relatively loose Cu/Cu2O(100) exhibited stronger interaction with the encapsulated Al2O3 overlayer than the densely packed Cu/Cu2O(111) crystal facet, promoting the generation of more OVs. Further investigations through CH3OH-temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), CH3OHH2O TPSR and in situ DRIFTs of MSR confirmed that the optimal Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 structure follows the *HCOOCH3 pathway, involving successive steps of methanol dehydrogenation into formaldehyde (*CH3OH → *HCHO), the formation of methyl formate (CH3OH+*HCHO → *HCOOCH3), the hydrolysis of methyl formate (*HCOOCH3+H2O → *HCOO+*CH3OH), and the decomposition of formic acid into CO2 and H2 (*HCOO → CO2+H2). The synergetic effects of encapsulated Al2O3 overlayers and Cu/Cu(100) facilitated the dehydrogenation of CH3OH into HCHO and enhanced the hydrolysis of methyl formate, achieving an improved hydrogen production rate of 6.91 mmol·g-1·h-1 with a CO selectivity below 0.17 %. 2 Experimental details 2.1 Chemicals and materials All chemical reagents, including methanol, ethanol, CuCl2·2H2O, Al(NO3)3·9H2O, l-ascorbic acid (L-AA), NaOH, and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, Mw 30,000), purchased from Macklin Chemical Co., were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Ultrapure water (18.2 MΩ·cm) was used throughout the entire experimental process. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis During hydrothermal synthesis, 4 mmol of CuCl2·2H2O and 1 mmol of Al(NO3)3·9H2O were dissolved in 250 mL of aqueous solution. Then, 35.52 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, Mw 30,000) was dissolved in the prepared solution to achieve the desired R (representing the molar ratio of PVP to CuCl2·2H2O), and the values of R were set to 0 and 80 [36,37]. Then, 50.0 mL of NaOH aqueous solution (2.0 mol·L-1) was added dropwise into the resulting transparent light green solution. During the process, the color of the solution became blue–green turbid, and then turned to dark brown. After the solution was stirred for 0.5 h,L-ascorbic acid solution (40.0 mL and 0.6 M) was added dropwise into the dark brown solution. A turbid red suspension was gradually formed and allowed to stand for 3 h. All procedures were performed under constant mechanical stirring, and the resulting solution was heated in a water bath at 55 °C. The resulting precipitate was collected through centrifugation, then washed three times with distilled water and absolute ethanol twice to remove residual inorganic ions and polymer, and finally dried under vacuum at 70 °C for 12 h for further use. The samples with a fully exposed (100) facet at R = 0 or (111) facet at R = 80 are denoted as Cu2O(100) or Cu2O(111), respectively [38,39]. Similarly, the (100)-faceted Al-doped Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 and Al-free Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 were synthesized using the same procedure. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The physicochemical properties of catalysts were systematically analyzed using multiple characterization techniques. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (35 kV, 25 mA) in the 2θ range of 20–80° at a scanning rate of 10° min-1. The actual contents of Cu and Al in the catalyst were quantitatively analyzed by inductively coupled plasma−atomic emission spectroscopy on a Thermo IRIS Intrepid IIXSP ICP. Morphological features, nanostructures, and surface elemental distributions were characterized using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Talos F200X, 200 kV) equipped with high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) measurements were performed using a TESCAN Essence™ energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) probe aberration-corrected microscope coupled with a Bruker energy-dispersive spectrometer. Surface chemical states were analyzed using an ESCALab250XI photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, Thermo Fisher Scientific), with binding energy calibration based on the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. 2.4 Experiment methods of TPR, TPD, and TPSR 2.4.1 H2-TPR To investigate the redox properties and Cu/Cu2O-Al interactions, hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were conducted on Al2O3@Cu2O and Cu2O catalysts with different crystal facets using an AutoChem 2920 chemisorption analyzer. At 300 °C, 50 mg of catalyst was pretreated under a flowing He atmosphere (50 mL/min) to remove adsorbed impurities. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, it was purged under 10 % H2/Ar (50 mL/min) until the baseline stabilized. Then, the sample was heated to 700 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The effluent gas was passed through a cold trap to remove water vapor and monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.4.2 CH3OH-TPD and CH3OHH2O TPSR To explore the desorption characteristics of CH3OH and H2O on the catalyst surface and their interaction behaviors, TPD and online mass spectrometry (ThermoStar GSD 320T) were conducted on the Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O catalytic system using an AutoChem 2950 HP chemisorption analyzer. CH3OH-TPD and methanol–water temperature-programmed surface reaction (CH3OHH2O TPSR) experiments were systematically performed as follows: first, 80 mg of pre-reduced catalyst was loaded into a quartz reactor and purged with high-purity He (60 mL/min) at 300 °C for 1 h to remove impurities. Saturated methanol vapor was introduced into the reaction system for 45 min via He bubbling to achieve adsorption saturation and then purged with He at 30 °C for 1 h to remove physically adsorbed molecules. TPD measurements were conducted under a He atmosphere at a linear temperature ramp (30–600 °C), and characteristic ion signals for H2 (m/z = 2), H2O (18), CO (28), CH3OH (31), CO2 (44), HCOOH (46), HCHO (30), and HCOOCH3 (60) were monitored using simultaneous mass spectrometry. In CH3OHH2O TPSR experiments, the catalyst, after identical pretreatment, was exposed to saturated water vapor for 45 min, purged for 1 h, and then switched to a methanol vapor atmosphere bubbled with He (carrier gas). The same temperature ramp (30–700 °C) was applied under a CH3OHHe mixed gas flow, with simultaneous tracking of dynamic changes in oxygenated intermediates and gaseous products. Comparing the product distributions from TPD and TPSR experiments effectively distinguishes simple desorption behaviors of methanol and water from surface synergistic reaction pathways, providing in situ dynamic evidence for elucidating active sites and reaction mechanisms. 2.5 In situ drifts experiment In situ diffuse-reflectance infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) measurements were performed using a Bruker FTIR spectrometer (INVENIO S) equipped with an MCT detector and a Harrick diffuse reflective cell. This experiment was conducted in diffuse-reflectance mode. The spectra were collected by accumulating 64 scans at a resolution of 4 cm-1. In this section, an in situ DRIFTS experiment for MSR was conducted by continuously introducing methanol–water-mixed vapor (molar ratio 1:3) into the reaction system through Ar carrier gas bubbling. The process began with high-purity Ar gas passing through a thermostatic saturator containing a liquid methanol–water mixture for 40 min to achieve quantitative vapor introduction. During data acquisition, a programmed temperature mode was used, where the temperature was initially ramped from 30 °C to 130 °C at 5 °C/min, and transient spectra were collected every 10 °C (every 2 min). After reaching 140 °C, the stepwise temperature was increased by 20 °C, with each temperature plateau maintained for 15 min for steady-state measurements, and characteristic spectra were recorded at the end of each plateau (15th min). The temperature was finally increased to 300 °C to cover the temperature range for MSR activity evaluation. This experimental design effectively captures the dynamic evolution of surface intermediates and provides real-time information on adsorbed species. 2.6 Catalytic performance evaluation MSR reactions were performed in a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor with an inner diameter of 6 mm. Before the test, the catalyst was sieved to a particle size range of 40–60 mesh (corresponding to 300–450 μm) using standard sieves, which eliminated the internal and external diffusion effect. Then, 0.2 g of catalyst was loaded between quartz wool plugs and in situ reduced at 220 °C under a flowing 10 % H2/Ar at atmospheric pressure for 1.5 h and switched to a N2 flow at 50 mL/min. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, a methanol and water mixture (molar ratio 3:1) was transferred into the vaporized reactor at 0.02 mL/min using a syringe pump operated at 160 °C using flowing N2 as the carrier gas (methanol WHSV = 5 h-1). The gas mixture exiting the reactor was effectively cooled using a condenser to capture residual unreacted CH3OH and H2O. After the gas mixture was dried, the gas products were analyzed online using a gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) for the quantitative detection of CO, CH₄, and CO2, while H2 content was measured using a TCD. The effluent gas flow rate was simultaneously monitored using a mass flow meter. Methanol conversion (Eq. (4)), CO selectivity (Eq. (5)), and H2 yield (Eq. (6)) were defined as follows: (4) MeOH Conversion ( % ) = F CO , out + F C H 4 , out + F C O 2 , out F MeOH , in x 100 (5) CO selectivity ( % ) = F CO , out F H 2 , out + F CO , out + F C H 4 , out + F C O 2 , out x 100 (6) H 2 production rate ( per catalyst weight : mmo l H 2 g cat − 1 h − 1 ) = F H 2 , out m x 60 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and physical property characterization The bulk structure of the Cu/Cu2O catalyst system was analyzed using XRD to investigate the effects of facets and Al2O3 species on various samples. As shown in Figs. 1 a and 1 b, the characteristic peaks of pre-reduction samples, including Al2O3@Cu2O(100), Al2O3@Cu2O(111), and Cu2O(100), were observed at 36.1°, 42.4°, and 61.4°, respectively, corresponding to the Cu2O phase (PDF#04–6541) [40]. In contrast, the peaks for post-reduction samples of Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(111) and Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100) were observed at 43.3°, 50.4°, and 74.2°, attributing to the metallic Cu phase (PDF#01–4609) [41]. Notably, no Al-related peaks were detected in the XRD patterns before or after reduction, indicating that Al2O3 species were highly dispersed on the Cu/Cu2O surface in accordance with the SEM results [42]. PVP, a non-ionic surfactant, contains easily polarized C = O functional groups in its repeating units. The electronegative oxygen atoms in C = O functional groups can strongly interact with the positively charged unsaturated Cu atoms on the {111} facets through electrostatic attraction and coordination, leading to selective adsorption and stabilization of the {111} facets. Therefore, the adsorption stabilized the {111} plane and hindered the growth rate perpendicular to it when PVP was introduced. The introduction of PVP exposed the {111} surfaces and produced truncated cubes. This systematic evolution, driven by the selective stabilization of {111} facets by PVP, ultimately led to the transition from cubic (dominated by {100} facets) to octahedral structures (dominated by {111} facets). The introduction of PVP to CuCl2·2H2O precursor changed the shape of Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100) from cubic to octahedral with eight (111) facets. After the introduction of Al2O3 and subsequent reduction, the cubic (100) and octahedral (111) structures were maintained [37]. Additionally, the detection of Al and O species in the EDS spectrum confirmed the formation of Al2O3 on the Cu surface (Figs. 2 a– 2 f), thereby establishing an inverse Al2O3/Cu structure. The interaction between Al2O3 and Cu led to the formation of a Cu-O interface structure, which stabilized Cu2O species on Cu/Cu2O. This stabilization process ultimately induced the structure of encapsulated Al2O3 overlayer on Cu/Cu2O. These results were consistent with HRTEM results (Figs. 3 a–3q). Compared with Cu/Cu2O(100)-260, the incorporation of Al2O3 species on Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O-260 induced lattice expansion and weakened Cu/Cu bonding as evidenced by the Cu(100) peak shifting to lower angles. After the introduction of Al2O3, the Cu(100) characteristic peak of Cu/Cu2O(111) shifted to a lower angle. However, the extent of the shift was significantly smaller than that observed for Cu/Cu2O(100), indicating that the interaction strength between Al2O3 species and Cu/Cu2O(100) was stronger than that between Al2O3 species and Cu/Cu2O(111). The lattice spacing of Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 was measured as 0.1893 nm [Cu(200), d = 0.1808 nm], consistent with XRD results. After the Al2O3 species were introduced to the system, the lattice spacing increased to 0.3046 nm, which corresponded to Cu2O(110) (d = 0.3019 nm). This increased lattice spacing indicated that more Cu2O species were stabilized due to the formation of Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O triple-phase interface. Consequently, the strong interfacial interaction between encapsulated Al2O3 and Cu/Cu2O inhibited continuous reduction of Cu2O to Cu, whereas Cu/Cu2O(100) was almost reduced to metallic Cu due to the absence of Al2O3 overlayer. After Al2O3 incorporation, similar encapsulated Al2O3 overlayers were formed on Cu/Cu2O(111) as Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(111)-260, showing a lattice spacing of 0.248 nm (Cu2O(111), d = 0.246 nm). 3.2 Identification of interfacial electronic properties The interfacial electronic structure and associated electron transfer mechanisms of inverse Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O-based catalysts were analyzed using high-resolution XPS, revealing Cu, Al, and O. Among Cu LMM Auger spectra of Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100), two characteristic peaks corresponding to Cu+ (917.4 eV, 51.1 %) and Cu0 (910.5, 913.6, and 920.2 eV, 48.9 %) were observed (Figs. 4 a– 4 c). Based on the ratio of the integral areas of Cu+ and total Cu species (Cu+/Cu0), Cu+ accounted for 51.1 %, while Cu0 species accounted for the remaining 48.9 %. In contrast, the Cu+ peaks of Cu/Cu2O(100)-260, which were centered at exhibited a lower Cu+ proportion of 44.8 %. Therefore, the incorporation of encapsulated Al2O3 overlayers shifted the peak of Cu+ species toward lower kinetic energy and increased the intensity of the Cu+ peak. These results showed that the stronger metal-support interaction was achieved on Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100) than that on Cu/Cu2O(100) due to the intensified electron transfers of Cu → Al2O3 at the interface of encapsulated Al2O3 overlayers and Cu/Cu2O(100). As shown in Fig. 4 b, the Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 with (100) facets exhibited a significantly higher Cu+ proportion of 51.1 % than Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(111)-260 (34.4 %), indicating that Al2O3 exhibited superior SMSIs on Cu/Cu2O(100) compared with Cu/Cu2O(111).The Al 2p spectra of Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 were split into two dominant peaks assigned to Al3+ (75.4 eV) and a disturbance peak of Cu LMM, respectively. The position of Al3+ for Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100) was significantly higher than that of Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(111)-260 (74.9 eV), indicating a higher positive charge on Al3+ in Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100), which featured a (100) facet (Fig. 4 d). When considering the reduction temperature, the relatively lower reduction temperature of 220 °C induced almost no change in the binding energy of Al3+. When the reduction temperature was increased to 260 °C, the binding energy of Al3+ initially significantly increased and slightly decreased at 300 °C. Among the reduction temperatures of 220 °C, 260 °C, and 300 °C, the highest positive charge for Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100) was achieved at 260 °C (Fig. 4 e). Cu LMM results revealed that the intensified electron transfers from Cu to Al2O3 preferentially followed the pathway of Cu to O rather than Cu to Al, indicating the absence of a Cu-Al interaction. Therefore, the charge density of O increased. To maintain electrical neutrality while generating stronger positively charged Al3+, more positively charged OVs were produced, as evidenced by the spectra of O 1 s (Fig. 4 f). As shown in Figs. 4 f– 4 h, the O 1 s spectra were divided into three distinct peaks due to lattice oxygen (529–530 eV) and oxygen vacancies (OVs, 531–532 eV) [30]. For Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260, the O 1 s spectrum featured two main peaks corresponding to lattice oxygen and OVs (531.3 eV, 52.1 %). Compared with the Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 (42.2 % OVs), the increased proportion of OVs in Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 s derived from Cu → O type interfacial charge transfers induced charge compensation (Fig. 4 f). Similarly, for the (100) facet exhibiting stronger charge transfers (Cu → O), the charge compensation mechanism increased the concentration of OVs (52.1 %) compared with the (111) crystal facet (39.0 %) (Fig. 4 g ). When focusing on the reduction temperature of Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O, the concentration of OVs became maximum at 220 °C (Fig. 4 h). However, as the reaction temperature increased to 300 °C, the OVs concentration decreased, accompanied by a significant reduction in the binding energy of the corresponding lattice oxygen and an accumulation of electrons around O. Additionally, the concentration of Al3+ species derived from Al 2p significantly increased. At high temperatures (260 °C and 300 °C), charge neutrality was mainly restored through an increase in the positive charge on Al 2p, whereas at the lower temperature of 220 °C, it was predominantly achieved by increasing OVs. Thus, the charge compensation mechanism induced by electron transfer from Cu to Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100) significantly varied across different temperatures. To further investigate the interaction strength between Cu and Al2O3 species in different samples and the kinetics of the reduction process, H2-TPR measurements were conducted. Compared with Cu/Cu2O(100)-260, the reduction peaks of Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 of α (220–300 °C) and β (300–350 °C) shifted to lower temperatures after Al2O3 species were introduced to the system (Fig. 4 i). This phenomenon can be attributed to the formation of an encapsulated Al2O3 overlayer, which weakens the Cu-O bond strength and facilitates its reduction. In contrast, the densely packed (111) facet on Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(111) exhibited higher reduction temperatures due to stable Cu-O coordination. 3.3 Elevation of catalytic performance 3.3.1 Catalytic performance of MSR Considering the crystal facet effect and the introduction of encapsulated Al2O3 species, the Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 featuring (100) facet and Al2O3 overlayers achieved a hydrogen production rate of 6.91 mmol·g-1·h-1 at 320 °C, which is 2.3 times higher than that of the Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 (4.19 mmol·g-1·h-1), with CO selectivity marginally increasing from 0.08 % to 0.17 % (Figs. 5 a and 5 d). Meanwhile, the hydrogen rate of Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 featuring (100) facets was 12 times (6.91 vs. 0.573 mmol·g-1·h-1) higher than that of Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(111)-260 featuring (111) facet, and its CO selectivity decreased by 26 % (from 0.66 % vs. 0.17 %) (Figs. 5 b and 5 e). Notably, ICP-OES analysis revealed that both Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 and Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(111)-260 exhibited closely matched Cu and Al contents, confirming similar overall metal loadings in the two catalysts (Table 1 ). Therefore, the influence of Cu or Al content on MSR performance can be excluded, indicating that the divergent catalytic performance primarily originates from differences in crystal facets. In addition, to reflect the intrinsic activity of the samples, the apparent activation energies (Ea) were ranked in the following order: Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 (56.99 kJ/mol) < Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(111)-260 (76.59 kJ/mol) < Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 (83.78 kJ/mol) < Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-300 (99.11 kJ/mol) (Figs. 5 g– 5 i). The lowest Ea for Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 indicated its superior kinetics, attributed to optimized (100) facet and encapsulated overlayers. 3.4 Proposed reaction mechanism Based on the identification of characteristic adsorbed intermediates, the reaction pathways of MSR can be categorized into formate (*HCOO), carbon monoxide (*CO), and methyl formate (*HCOOCH3) routes. In this study, in situ DRIFTs, CH3OH-TPD, and CH3OHH2O TPSR were separately used to capture the adsorbed and desorbed intermediate species during the MSR reaction process, thereby enabling the construction of a reaction pathway. 3.4.1 Investigation of adsorbed intermediate species As displayed in the in situ DRIFTS spectra of Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 (Figs. 6 a– 6 b), the C–O stretching vibration (νC–O) at 955–1108 cm-1 progressively intensified with temperature elevation (30–300 °C), indicating the dehydrogenation of OH bond on CH3OH and generation of methoxy species (*CH3O) (CH3OH → *CH3O + *H). The presence of C–H stretching vibrations (νC–H) at 2841 and 2922 cm-1 and OC-O vibrations at 1152–1557 cm-1 confirmed the formation of surface formate species (HCOO-) through hydrolysis of methyl formate intermediates (HCOOCH3 + H2O → HCOO- + CH3OH). Additionally, the O–H vibration (νO–H) at 3685 cm-1 originated from surface hydroxyl groups (*OH) formed through the partial dissociation of water. Meanwhile, the increasing intensity of ν C O 2 at 2356 cm-1 with rising temperature indicated efficient HCOO- decomposition to CO2 (HCOOH → CO2 + H2). Therefore, for Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260, the reaction pathway of MSR involved the hydrolysis of methyl formate (HCOOCH3) to formate (HCOO-) and the decomposition of *HCOO into CO2 and H2, confirming the HCOOCH3 pathway. Notably, no νCO peaks (1900–2100 cm-1) attributed to linearly adsorbed CO were detected, indicating the inhibition of further HCHO dehydrogenation to CO (HCHO → HCO → CO) on the (100) facet, consistent with CH3OHH2O TPSR results. 3.4.2 Investigation of products and desorbed intermediates CH3OH-TPD and CH3OHH2O TPSR equipped with a mass spectrometer were used to investigate desorption species (including reaction products and weakly adsorbed intermediates). In CH3OH-TPD experiments, Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 without Al2O3 overlayer exhibited H2 desorption peaks at 377.2 °C and 473.7 °C, along with CO2 desorption peaks at 129.3, 276.7, and 451.5 °C (Fig. 6 c). When encapsulated Al2O3 overlayers were established, the H2 desorption peaks of Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 shifted to lower temperatures of 266.8 °C and 430.1 °C with increased peak areas. Meanwhile, the initial CO2 desorption temperature decreased from 246.9 °C to 123.7 °C (Fig. 6 d). These results showed that the encapsulated Al2O3 overlayers facilitated both methanol dehydrogenation to CO and the oxidation of CO to CO2. Weak CO desorption peaks of Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 observed at 127.9 °C and 462.9 °C confirmed that HCHO was slightly dehydrogenated to CO. The CH3OHH2O TPSR results revealed that the desorption peaks of H2, CO2, CO, HCHO, HCOOH, and HCOOCH3 were detected on Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 at a synchronized temperature of 200 °C (Fig. 6 f). This synchronicity indicated the consistency of the kinetic rates of each elementary reaction step in MSR. The results of in situ DRIFTs of MSR revealed a *HCOOCH3 pathway involving methanol sequential dehydrogenation to formaldehyde, condensation of formaldehyde with methanol to form methyl formate, methyl formate hydrolysis to form formate, and the decomposition of formate into CO2 and H2. For the Cu/Cu2O(100) and Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(111) samples, the peak temperatures of H2, CO, and CO2 were significantly higher, while no significant signals assigned to HCHO, HCOOH, or *HCOOCH3 were observed (Figs. 6 c– 6 h). These results showed that, in comparison to Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100), the dehydrogenation of CH3OH to HCHO and the subsequent condensation reaction between HCHO and CH3OH to form HCOOCH3 represent the kinetically slower steps. 3.5 Discussion on structure−activity correlation The MSR performance of Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100) (2.3-fold higher H2 yield, 0.17 % CO selectivity) was superior to that of Al2O3-free Cu/Cu2O(100)-260. This disparity in performance can be attributed to the synergetic effects of encapsulated Al2O3 overlayers and (100) facets. The encapsulated Al2O3 overlayer coupled with Cu/Cu2O(100) established triphasic interfaces that exhibited enhanced SMSIs due to intensified electron transfers from Cu to Al2O3. The electron transfers from Cu to Al2O3 stabilized the Cu+ in Cu/Cu2O(100) structure, thus accelerating methanol dehydrogenation to HCHO (CH cleavage). Meanwhile, the electron transfers from Cu to Al2O3 mainly followed the Cu → O pathway, with electrons accumulating around O. Highly positively charged Al3+ ions and OVs were formed to maintain electrical neutrality, forming Al3+-OVs active pairs that effectively facilitated the hydrolysis of methyl formate. 4 Conclusion In this study, an inverse Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 catalyst with encapsulated Al2O3 overlayers and (100) facet was prepared. This catalyst achieved optimal MSR performance. The synergetic effects of inverse encapsulated Al2O3 overlayers and (100) facet facilitated the electron transfers from Cu to Al2O3 with stabilized Cu/Cu2O(100) and positive-charged Al3+-OVs induced by charge compensation. This process accelerated CH3OH dehydrogenation to HCHO (CH cleavage) and the hydrolysis of methyl formate. This study provides a strategy of coupling an optimal facet with inversely encapsulated oxide overlayers for rationally designing efficient Cu-based MSR catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Copper-based alumina (Cu/Al2O3) catalysts are promising for low-temperature methanol steam reforming. However, the susceptibility of Cu species to sinter in the reaction atmosphere significantly compromises their stability and intrinsic activity. In this study, we developed crystal-facet-mediated inverse Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O catalysts with triphasic interfaces, exhibiting excellent performance for methanol steam reforming. Under optimal conditions, the Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 catalysts featuring exposed (100) facets activated at 260 °C achieved the optimal hydrogen production rate of 6.91 mmol·g-1·h-1 and the lowest apparent activation energy of 56.99 kJ/mol among comparable systems. This superior performance was attributed to the enhanced strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) at the triphasic interfaces of encapsulated Al2O3 overlayer on Cu/Cu2O(100). This interaction accelerated interfacial electron transfer from Cu to Al2O3, thereby facilitating the generation of oxygen vacancies (OVs) while suppressing the reduction of Cu2O to metallic Cu. Consequently, the SMSI-driven process enhanced the stability of the critical Cu+ sites. In addition, the metastable Cu (100) facet, possessing a loosely arranged atomic structure, further intensified the interaction between Cu and Al2O3, thus forming more OVs than the densely packed Cu (111) facet. The combination of in situ DRIFTs, CH3OHH2O TPSR, and CH3OH-TPD analyses revealed the *HCOOCH3 pathway on inverse Al2O3@Cu/Cu2O(100)-260 catalysts with accelerated steps of continuous dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde (CH3OH → HCHO) and hydrolysis of methanol methyl formate (HCOOCH3 + H2O → HCOO- + CH3OH), resulting in the excellent MSR activity. This work highlights the critical role of facet-dependent SMSIs and interfacial engineering for efficient hydrogen production.
